Sacred Art Chicago, from the ground up.

Summary

The client, Sacred Art, was in need of a complete overhaul of her current site to best display the artists she carries and to allow for ease of use.

Problem

Sacred Art's original site was powered through Wordpress and based on a standard template. The template did not serve their particular needs and was often inadequate for their purposes.

The store owner would often neglect updating the site because the interface was not intuitive enough for her to want to use. As such it served neither her nor her customers who came their for updates, news and artist information.

Solution

Bright and Graphic: First and foremost I built out the HTML and CSS/SASS with a mind towards showcases all the amazing talent that Sacred Art carries. Swapping out simple links for graphic, bright cards directs shoppers between categories of art. For pages that were originally completely text based I developed a two column responsive layout that could be used over and over to sneak in a few more photos next to liven up even something as boring as the FAQ page.

Easy to use CMS: Without the ability to easily use the CMS its all pretty useless for the client. So, I decided to build Kate a CMS from scratch with Ruby/Rails that was both intuitive and simple. For example, when viewing all the artists in a particular category admin buttons were added to add artists at the top of the page where they couldn't be missed. Each artists card itself had edit and delete buttons so updating was as simple as scrolling through an alphabetical list.
To simplify even further I built an admin control panel for her to access all the controls in one easy location with instructions right there on the page so she wouldn't be required to reference email instructions or outside sources. The idea was a one stop shop for all her CMS needs.

Storage and Database: With a custom built CMS came storage issues. For the database SQLite was used in development and Postgres for our test site (as heroku has SQLite issues). Databases were set up to support the CMS's ability to add/edit/delete artists, change shop hours, FAQ's and Events. Considerations were given for simplicity of use by automatically alphabetizing the database, a problem which plagued the original site. An event index can be seen by the admin but only current or upcoming events display to customers, simplifying the upkeep for Kate. Small changes like these were aimed at making a big difference in the site's upkeep, now she can focus on her customers and her artists rather than making sure outdated events were deleted.

Ecommerce enabled: The original site had no way to receive online orders which was a real drawback. By integrating Square, the payment processor Kate already used I was able to easily add ecommerce functionality. This will open up a brand new revenue stream for Sacred Art with online shipping and instore pick up options.

Responsive: I was sure to make the site as responsive as possible, often altering the layout, and which elements were displayed at all to make the mobile experience as easy to use as possible. Utilizing according layouts for the FAQ and overflow set to scroll for some of the longer bios I was able to give user's thumbs a little rest while accessing via mobile.

Results
